text: 1.  Introduction to the Foundation Level Extensions
label: h1

text: This overview document is intended for anyone with an interest in the ISTQB Foundation Level
label: other

text: Extensions who wants a high-level introduction to the leading principles and an overview of the individual
label: other

text: extension syllabi.
label: other

text: From time to time, ISTQB will update this document to reflect any additional extensions that shall be
label: other

text: introduced for the Foundation Level, or to reflect major changes in existing ones. Publications of the
label: other

text: updated document will be available on the ISTQB website.
label: other

text: The ISTQB Foundation and Advanced Level syllabi have been defined and have been on the market for
label: other

text: some time. New topics emerge due to technology and methodology changes in the market which often
label: other

text: are brought into the ISTQB program as new Expert Level syllabi. However, not all topics are suited for the
label: other

text: Expert Level. For this reason, the extension syllabi are established at the Foundation Level to expand the
label: other

text: ISTQB program to incorporate new or updated knowledge. New extensions shall be discussed and
label: other

text: introduced by the ISTQB periodically. Extensions may be established at the Advanced Level as well, but
label: other

text: that is beyond the scope of this document.
label: other

text: The following Foundation Level Extension syllabus has been released:
label: other

text: Agile Tester
label: other

text: In this document, each Foundation Level Extension syllabus is summarized and the associated Business
label: other

text: Outcomes are stated. The Business Outcomes communicate what can be expected from a person who
label: other

text: achieves a Foundation Level Extension Certification in a particular subject area (e.g., Agile Tester), and
label: other

text: will outline the benefits for companies that are considering the development of specific testing skills at this
label: other

text: level.

text: 2.  Introduction to Foundation Level Agile Tester Extension
label: other

text: The certification for Foundation Level Extension – Agile Tester is designed for professionals who are
label: other

text: working within Agile environments. It is also for professionals who are planning to start implementing
label: other

text: Agile methods in the near future, or are working within companies that plan to do so, The certification
label: other

text: provides an advantage for those who would like to know the required Agile activities, roles, methods, and
label: other

text: methodologies specific to their role.
label: other

text: 2.1 Intended Audience
label: other

text: The Foundation Level Extension – Agile Tester qualification is aimed at four main groups of professionals:
label: other

text: 1. Professionals who have achieved in-depth testing experience in traditional methods and would
label: other

text: like to get an Agile Tester Certificate.
label: other

text: 2. Junior professional testers who are just starting in the testing profession, have received the
label: other

text: Foundation Level certificate, and would like to know more about the tester’s role in an Agile
label: other

text: environment.
label: other

text: 3. Professionals who are relatively new to testing and are required to implement test approaches,
label: other

text: methods and techniques in their day to day job in Agile projects.
label: other

text: 4. Professionals who are experienced in their role (including unit testing) and need more
label: other

text: understanding and knowledge about how to perform and manage testing on all levels in Agile
label: other

text: projects.
label: other

text: These professionals include people who are in roles such as testers, test analysts, test engineers, test
label: other

text: consultants, test managers, user acceptance testers, and software developers.
label: other

text: This Foundation Level Extension – Agile Tester certification may also be appropriate for anyone who
label: other

text: wants a deeper understanding of software testing in the Agile world, such as project managers, quality
label: other

text: managers, software development managers, business analysts, IT directors, and management
label: other

text: consultants.
label: other

text: 2.2 Career Paths for Testers
label: other

text: Building on the Foundation Level, the Agile Tester Extension supports the definition of career paths for
label: other

text: professional testers. A person with the Agile Tester certificate has extended the broad understanding of
label: other

text: testing acquired at the Foundation Level to enable him or her to work effectively as a professional tester in
label: other

text: an Agile project.
label: other

text: People possessing an ISTQB Foundation Level Extension – Agile Tester certificate may use the Certified
label: other

text: Tester Foundation Level acronym CTFL-AT.
label: other

text: 2.3 Learning Objectives
label: other

text: In general, the Foundation Level syllabus is examinable at a K1 level, i.e., the candidate will recognize,
label: other

text: remember and recall terms and concepts stated in the Foundation Level syllabus.
label: other

text: In addition, all Foundation Level syllabus learning objectives are examinable at the same K- level in an
label: other

text: extension exam.

text: This section lists the Business Outcomes expected of a candidate who has achieved the Foundation Level
label: other

text: Extension – Agile Tester certification.
label: other

text: An Agile Tester can…
label: other

text: AFM1  Collaborate in a cross-functional Agile team being familiar with principles and basic
label: other

text: practices of Agile software development.
label: other

text: AFM2  Adapt existing testing experience and knowledge to Agile values and principles.
label: other

text: AFM3  Support the Agile team in planning test-related activities.
label: other

text: AFM4  Apply relevant methods and techniques for testing in an Agile project.
label: other

text: AFM5  Assist the Agile team in test automation activities.
label: other

text: AFM6  Assist business stakeholders in defining understandable and testable user stories,
label: other

text: scenarios, requirements and acceptance criteria as appropriate.
label: other

text: AFM7  Work and share information with other team members using effective communication
label: other

text: styles and channels.
label: other

text: In general, a Certified Tester Foundation Level – Agile Tester is expected to have acquired the necessary
label: other

text: skills to working effectively within an Agile team and environment.

label: other

text: Chapter 1: Agile Software Development
label: other

text: The tester should remember the basic concept of Agile software development based on the Agile
label: other

text: Manifesto.
label: other

text: The tester should understand the advantages of the whole-team approach and the benefits of
label: other

text: early and frequent feedback.
label: other

text: The tester should recall Agile software development approaches.
label: other

text: The tester should be able to write testable user stories in collaboration with developers and
label: other

text: business representatives.
label: other

text: The tester should understand how retrospectives can be used as a mechanism for process
label: other

text: improvement in Agile projects.
label: other

text: The tester should understand the use and purpose of continuous integration.
label: other

text: The tester should know the differences between iteration and release planning, and how a tester
label: other

text: adds value in each of these activities.

text: Background
label: other

text: First, some background on the ODL. For the last two years the Ontario Library Association
label: other

text: has acted as a catalyst, bringing together the stakeholders needed to create the Ontario
label: other

text: Digital Library (ODL). These stakeholders include Ontario’s 5000+ public libraries, university,
label: other

text: college, and school libraries, as well as Ontario government ministries.
label: other

text: Libraries that serve very different clientele recognize that by working together they can create
label: other

text: seamless access to quality electronic library services. Through the ODL, students will be
label: other

text: able to explore a topic at school, use the same child-safe resources after school (either at
label: other

text: home or at a public library), enter college or university with a knowledge of how to use
label: other

text: electronic resources that are still available and then, after graduation, continue to use these
label: other

text: skills and resources at work or at home.
label: other

text: We are moving into a period of convergence. With convergence we no longer have to license
label: other

text: commercial products as individual libraries or institutions. We can work together to spend our
label: other

text: money wisely. The provincial government has made this possible by working hard to provide
label: other

text: all Ontarians with a stable, high-speed communications infrastructure. While there is still a
label: other

text: great deal of work needed to improve this infrastructure, libraries are beginning to plan how
label: other

text: best to exploit communications technology. We can reduce barriers to access and create the
label: other

text: content infrastructure needed to support a knowledge society.
label: other

text: The concept of an ODL is a key element in  The Roadmap to Prosperity , a strategic plan to
label: other

text: envision and attain Ontario’s economic goal prepared by the Ontario Jobs and Investment
label: other

text: Board. The OJIB strategic plan recommends an electronic library to “connect students to new
label: other

text: workplaces, new sources of information and applied learning opportunities”. The ODL will do
label: other

text: that and much more. The ODL will connect students to electronic information, and will also
label: other

text: leverage this investment to help connect all citizens to the electronic information they need as
label: other

text: they make decisions, solve problems and enhance their quality of life.
label: other

text: Libraries have long been a key delivery point for public services. The ODL will allow that
label: other

text: delivery point to move closer to citizens, into the smallest of libraries and even into living
label: other

text: rooms.
label: other

text: Libraries have a long tradition of using a practical, consultative approach to solving problems,
label: other

text: and of learning from others. The ODL is a very practical solution to various problems.
label: other

text: Jurisdiction-wide digital libraries are very practical and very real. The ODL we propose is
label: other

text: leading edge for Ontario but several jurisdictions have forged the path with collaborative
label: other

label: other

text: Over the last 6 years, three separate pesticide use injunctions have resulted from litigation
label: other

text: between the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) and environmental
label: other

text: advocacy groups such as Californians Against Toxic Substances (CATS), Washington
label: other

text: Toxics Coalition and the Center for Biological Diversity.
label: other

text: The first injunction was put into place in February of 2004, and is known as the “Salmonid
label: other

text: Injunction.” It resulted from a lawsuit by environmental and fishery groups alleging that
label: other

text: U.S. EPA failed to solicit National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) formal consultation
label: other

text: on the risks from 38 pesticides to 26 distinct populations of Chinook salmon, Coho Salmon
label: other

text: and Steelhead. This injunction imposes prohibitions on the use of 38 active ingredients,
label: other

text: 100 yards by air and 20 yards by ground from Salmon Supporting Waters. It also requires
label: other

text: U.S. EPA to consult with NMFS on the potential hazards posed by the 38 active ingredients
label: other

text: to Salmon populations. The first round of consultations in 2008 resulted in a Biological
label: other

text: Opinion for chlorpyrifos, diazinon and malathion. The Department of Pesticide Regulation
label: other

text: (DPR) expressed disagreement with the Biological Opinion and posted comments to the
label: other

text: public docket. The Biological Opinion proposed buffers of 500 feet for ground applications
label: other

text: and 1000 feet for aerial applications. Additionally, it imposes requirements for fish kill
label: other

text: reporting, runoff prevention measures and environmental monitoring. In response,
label: other

text: U.S. EPA decided to impose variable buffers depending on application rate + droplet size +
label: other

text: size of adjacent body of water. Nevertheless, for aerial applications the resulting buffers are
label: other

text: still almost 1000 feet. For ground applications, the resulting buffers can be a minimum of
label: other

text: 100 feet.
label: other

text: In November of 2009, U.S EPA submitted 40 draft California Bulletins for chlorpyrifos,
label: other

text: diazinon and malathion. The bulletins were reviewed by DPR’s Endangered Species
label: other

text: Program staff and comments sent to U.S. EPA. In January of 2010, U.S. EPA submitted the
label: other

text: revised bulletins, including a test version of an application intended to help pesticide
label: other

text: applicators calculate the corresponding buffer for their intended application rate, droplet
label: other

text: size and body of water adjacent to the application site. Once these bulletins are finalized,
label: other

text: they will be posted on U.S. EPA’s Bulletins Live Web site at
label: other

text: < http://137.227.242.131/espp_front/view.jsp >. U.S. EPA is asking registrants of
label: other

text: chlorpyrifos, diazinon and malathion to voluntarily modify labels of pesticides containing
label: other

text: these active ingredients and refer users to the Bulletins Live Web site in order to find out
label: other

text: which buffer size applies to the product they intend to apply. Registrants will be granted

text: The second injunction is known as the “Stipulated Injunction and Order for Protection of
label: other

text: California Red-Legged Frog.” Effective on October 20, 2006, the lawsuit by the Center for
label: other

text: Biological Diversity alleged that U.S. EPA failed to solicit U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service
label: other

text: (FWS) formal consultation on the risks from 66 pesticides to California red-legged frog. It
label: other

text: imposes prohibitions for use of 66 active ingredients - 200 feet by air, and 60 feet by
label: other

text: ground from California red-legged frog’s aquatic and upland habitats occurring in
label: other

text: 33 counties. As with the Salmonid injunction, the Ninth District Court in Seattle ordered
label: other

text: U.S. EPA to initiate formal consultations with the FWS, and schedule it in such a way that
label: other

text: it can be completed in approximately 5 years. Since 2007, U.S. EPA has been working on
label: other

text: effects determinations for all 66 active ingredients included in this injunction. They are

text: concurrently submitting them to the US Fish & Wildlife Service for their analysis and
label: other

text: expected Biological Opinions.

text: The third and latest injunction has not yet been finalized. It is still in draft form, but is
label: other

text: referred to as the “Bay Area Stipulated Injunction and Proposed Order.” This lawsuit by the
label: other

text: Center for Biological Diversity charges U.S. EPA with failure to consult with FWS on the
label: other

text: risks from 74 active ingredients to 11 listed species in the San Francisco Bay Area. Eight
label: other

text: counties are affected: Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, Napa, San Mateo, Santa Clara,
label: other

text: Solano and Sonoma. In its draft form, the injunction imposes different “no-use” buffers for
label: other

text: some of the 74 active ingredients, depending on the type of species. The species included
label: other

text: are: Alameda whipsnake, Bay checkerspot butterfly, California clapper rail, California
label: other

text: freshwater shrimp, California tiger salamander, Delta smelt, salt marsh harvest mouse, San
label: other

text: Francisco garter snake, San Joaquin kit fox, tidewater goby and Valley elderberry longhorn
label: other

text: beetle. The buffers imposed by this injunction range from 100 to 700 feet for ground
label: other

text: applications, and from 200 to 700 feet for aerial applications.
label: other

text: During the public comment period, DPR recommended U.S. EPA replace the proposed
label: other

label: other

text: All these injunctions share some common denominators:
label: other

text: 1) They have resulted from the lack of consultation by U.S. EPA on the effects of
label: other

text: “pesticide x” on “species y” with the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service (FWS) or National
label: other

text: Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS).
label: other

text: 2) They impose a consultation schedule between U.S. EPA and FWS or NMFS, typically
label: other

text: 4 to 6 years minimum.
label: other

text: 3) Public vector control and invasive weed control programs are exempt. However, in the
label: other

text: case of the Salmonid Injunction, the use limitations resulting from consultation on
label: other

text: chlorpyrifos, diazinon and malathion do not provide exemptions for vector control or
label: other

text: invasive weed control programs.
label: other

text: 4) They can only be enforced through citizen lawsuits. Federal, State, County and other
label: other

text: local authorities are “vacated’ from enforcing them.
label: other

text: 5) As products go through consultation, if deemed “not likely to adversely affect” a
label: other

text: species they will be taken off the injunction list.
label: other

label: other

text: be enforced through labeling, as is the case of chlorpyrifos, diazinon and malathion.
label: other

text: This process is very contentious. It also affects DPR, since each injunction comes with its
label: other

text: own set of buffers and species. DPR’s comprehensive, programmatic approach to
label: other

text: protection of endangered species is being impacted by the multitude of injunctions and
label: other

text: their litigation-derived buffers. Also, the imposition of court-ordered absolute buffers
label: other

text: discourages good land stewardship efforts. Growers, who in previous years might have
label: other

text: managed their fields to include field-edge vegetation cover, hedgerows, etc., now see their
label: other

text: habitat enhancement efforts as a potential liability if listed species move in. Under these
label: other

text: injunctions -even with exemptions- some invasive weed programs are still facing no-use
label: other

text: zones that become refuges for noxious weeds like  Arundo sp.  Furthermore, since the lists
label: other

label: other

label: title

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: h1

text: •	 Sharing sensitive personal and non-personal data without adequate safeguards can exacerbate
label: other

text: risks for crisis-affected people, humanitarian organizations and donors.
label: other

text: •	 Donors regularly request data from the organizations they fund in order to fulfil their obligations
label: other

text: and objectives. Some of these requests relate to sensitive information and data which needs to
label: other

text: be protected in order to mitigate risk.
label: other

text: •	 Common objectives for data sharing with donors include: (i) situational awareness and
label: other

text: programme design; (ii) accountability and transparency; and (iii) legal, regulatory, and policy
label: other

text: requirements.
label: other

text: •	 Common constraints related to sharing data with donors include: (i) lack of regulatory framework
label: other

text: for responsibly managing sensitive non-personal data; (ii) capacity gaps; and (iii) purpose
label: other

text: limitation.
label: other

text: •	 Donors and humanitarian organizations can take the following steps to minimize risks while
label: other

text: maximizing benefits when sharing sensitive data: (i) reviewing and clarifying the formal or
label: other

text: informal frameworks that govern the collection and sharing of disaggregated data; (ii) formalizing
label: other

text: and standardising requests for sensitive data; (iii) investing in data management capacities of
label: other

text: staff and organisations; and (iv) adopting common principles for donor data management.

text: INTRODUCTION
label: h1

text: Donors have an important role in the humanitarian data ecosystem, both as drivers of increased data
label: other

text: collection and analysis, and as direct users of data. This is not a new phenomenon; the need for
label: other

text: accountability and transparency in the use of donor funding is broadly understood and respected. However,
label: other

text: in recent years, donors have begun requesting data that can be sensitive. This includes personal data about
label: other

text: beneficiaries and various forms of disaggregated data, such as household-level survey results and data
label: other

text: about the delivery of assistance disaggregated by demographic and/or group dimensions (e.g. ethnicity,
label: other

text: protection group, etc.).
label: other

text: Concerns around requests for such data have led donors and humanitarian organizations to place more
label: other

text: emphasis on identifying strategies for data responsibility: the safe, ethical and effective management
label: other

text: of data. Data responsibility requires donors and humanitarian organizations to take actions that help
label: other

text: minimize risks while maximizing benefits of data. This is particularly challenging in cases where donors
label: other

text: request sensitive data. For example, the screening of aid recipients, which is often used to justify requests
label: other

text: for personal data, is not only difficult to practically implement, but also highly problematic in terms of
label: other

text: principled aid.
label: other

text: Because there are well-established and accepted standards and mechanisms for sharing financial information with donors, including a role for external
label: other

text: audits, requests for financial data are not included in this guidance note. This guidance note deals with sensitive personal and non-personal data.

text: DONOR REQUESTS FOR DATA
label: h1

text: Donors regularly request data from their partners in order to fulfil different obligations and objectives.
label: other

text: These requests can be either formal or informal.
label: other

text: •	 Formal requests
label: other

text: tend to be included in grant agreements in relation to reporting criteria, and are
label: other

text: typically based on legal requirements such as compliance with counter-terrorism laws. Such requests
label: other

text: tend to be negotiated at the outset of a partnership or grant agreement, and are usually made in
label: other

text: writing and scheduled in advance.
label: other

text: •	 Informal requests
label: other

text: concern information or data that typically fall outside of the normal scope  of
label: other

text: reporting. These ad-hoc requests often carry implicit value, meaning that while they are not
label: other

text: formally required, delivering this supplementary data is deemed beneficial for an organization’s
label: other

text: ongoing engagement and partnership with a donor. These requests represent a greater dilemma for
label: other

text: humanitarian actors.
label: other

text: Few donors have formal data sharing policies or guidelines in place.  There is also a lack of shared
label: other

text: understanding of terminology and of the objectives and risks around data sharing. There are different
label: other

text: definitions and understanding of data-related risks, leading to inconsistent and sometimes contradictory
label: other

text: practices around sharing potentially sensitive data with donors in a particular context.

text: OBJECTIVES FOR DATA SHARING WITH DONORS
label: h1

text: The most commonly identified objectives for donors requesting sensitive data from partners are
label: other

text: situational awareness and programme design; accountability and transparency; and legal, regulatory, and
label: other

text: policy requirements.
label: other

text: Situational awareness and programme design
label: other

text: Donors seek information and data from humanitarian organizations in order to understand and react
label: other

text: to changes in humanitarian contexts. This allows donors to improve their own programme design and
label: other

text: evaluation, prevent duplication of assistance, identify information gaps, and ensure appropriate targeting
label: other

text: of assistance.
label: other

text: Accountability and transparency
label: other

text: Donors and humanitarian organizations have an obligation to account for their activities. Data can enable
label: other

text: donors to explain and defend funding on foreign aid to taxpayers.
label: other

text: Legal, regulatory, and policy requirements
label: other

text: Donors are subject to certain national and international legal requirements, including political, legal and
label: other

text: statutory requirements related to counter-terrorism, migration and law enforcement. In many cases,
label: other

text: donors might want to use data to verify their compliance with these different requirements. Some donors
label: other

text: include counterterrorism clauses in their grant agreements, which are intended to ensure that their funds
label: other

text: are not used to benefit designated terrorist groups.  Similarly, donors might include clauses to cover anti-
label: other

text: bribery, anti-fraud and anti-corruption measures.
label: other

text: CONSTRAINTS FOR DATA SHARING WITH DONORS
label: h1

text: Despite these objectives, data sharing with donors is not without its constraints, which include a lack of
label: other

text: regulatory frameworks for responsibly managing sensitive non-personal data, capacity gaps and lack of
label: other

text: purpose limitation.
label: other

text: Lack of regulatory frameworks for responsibly managing sensitive non-personal data
label: other

text: The sensitivity of personal data is generally well-known and addressed by a variety of policy and regulatory
label: other

text: frameworks, but the same cannot be said for sensitive non-personal data. Protecting groups and their
label: other

text: data remains challenging due to the current gaps in regulation and guidance and the overall lack of
label: other

text: understanding regarding the sensitivity of non-personal data. These data policy gaps increase the risk of
label: other

text: sensitive data not being stored or protected adequately or shared inadvertently by partners in order to
label: other

text: satisfy donors’ requests.
label: other

text: Capacity gaps
label: other

text: Responding to ad-hoc data sharing requests from donors can be viewed as an additional burden to
label: other

text: humanitarian responders, diverting critical time, resources and focus away from other implementing
label: other

text: activities.  Insufficient funding for data-related capacity development has limited many organizations’
label: other

text: ability to provide their staff with the skills and resources required for managing data responsibly.  Gaps
label: other

text: in capacity to fulfil donor requirements might also deter smaller and/or local NGOs from seeking funding,
label: other

text: undermining localization efforts.

text: Purpose limitation
label: other

text: The principle of purpose limitation requires that data is only collected for specified, explicit and legitimate
label: other

text: purposes, and that it not be processed further in a manner that would be incompatible with those
label: other

text: purposes.  Even when donors specify legitimate reasons for requesting data in-line with the original
label: other

text: purposes for which the data was collected (e.g. the delivery of humanitarian assistance), it can be difficult
label: other

text: to ensure that the data will not be used for other purposes once shared. Data used out of context and for
label: other

text: purposes that are not known at the time of sharing, or retained past the intended retention for a defined
label: other

text: purpose represents a violation, even if unintended, of the data subjects’ rights.

text: RECOMMENDATIONS
label: h1

text: In view of the objectives and constraints detailed above, the Centre, the Humanitarian Policy Group (HPG)
label: other

text: at ODI, the ICRC, and the Human Security Division of the Swiss Federal Department of Foreign Affairs
label: other

text: recommend that donors and humanitarian organizations take the following steps to minimize risks while
label: other

text: maximizing benefits when sharing sensitive data:
label: other

text: •	 Reviewing and clarifying the formal or informal frameworks that govern the collection and
label: other

text: sharing of disaggregated data
label: other

text: Donors and partners should examine the official, formal requirements and ad-hoc, informal
label: other

text: requirements of data sharing, and analyse partner and donor staff interpret whether requirements
label: other

text: correctly and consistently. They should assess whether there are implicit conditionalities between the
label: other

text: willingness to share disaggregated data and the ability of different organizations to access and sustain
label: other

text: funding from donors.
label: other

text: •	 Formalizing and standardizing requests for sensitive data
label: other

text: When sensitive data is required to meet a mutually agreed objective, donors should formalize and
label: other

text: standardize their requests for such data. Requests should be made in writing and should specify
label: other

text: which data is requested, the format desired, and the intended use of the data. Donors should only
label: other

text: request the information required to meet the specified purpose for which it is being requested and
label: other

text: should indicate a timeline for destruction of the data. Humanitarian organisations should document
label: other

text: all requests for data and ensure consistency in responding to these requests over time.
label: other

text: •	 Investing in data management capacities of staff and organizations
label: other

text: Donors and humanitarian organizations should identify opportunities to invest in building data
label: other

text: management expertise especially for non-technical staff. The donor community is uniquely positioned
label: other

text: to encourage data responsibility by  providing additional  resources for training and capacity building.
label: other

text: •	 Adopting common principles for donor data management
label: other

text: The sector already has a range of principles and commitments to inform different aspects of
label: other

text: humanitarian donorship.  However, these do not sufficiently address concerns related to data
label: other

text: responsibility. Donors and partners should engage in the development of common principles and

label: other

text: False Negatives
label: other

text: A false negative occurs when no drought impact is predicted but drought conditions occur.
label: other

text: The team could consider additional mitigation strategies such as the use of citizen science or
label: other

text: ground observations to complement the forecast-based trigger.
label: other

text: Insufficient Data
label: other

text: Insufficient data refers to the gaps in impact data used to verify the forecast predictions.
label: other

text: Insufficient data might limit the precise prediction of forecasted humanitarian impact and
label: other

text: expose local populations to adverse humanitarian impact induced by a drought event, requiring
label: other

text: a large-scale humanitarian response ex-post. The team should consider the feasibility of adding
label: other

text: further vulnerability layers in future iterations of the model.
label: other

text: False Positives
label: other

text: A false positive happens when drought impact is predicted but no drought conditions occur.
label: other

text: Anticipatory action follows the ‘no regret’ principle, but a false alarm can still lead to inadequate
label: other

text: resource allocation with a high potential impact on affected communities. The anticipatory
label: other

text: action framework could indicate a precise mitigation strategy in a clearer manner.
label: other

text: Lack of Trust and Ownership
label: other

text: Lack of trust and ownership refers to the limited involvement of local and regional authorities in
label: other

text: the model design and validation. This may lead to little ownership and trust put into the model
label: other

text: and eventually to political blockages in activations. In future framework versions a clear strategy
label: other

text: for the involvement of affected populations and an approach to accountability to affected
label: other

text: populations should be identified.
label: other

text: Lack of Transparency
label: other

text: Lack of transparency refers to the algorithms not being made available or not being transparent.
label: other

text: The anticipatory action framework should reflect clearer strategies to engage with local leaders
label: other

text: to better understand what is happening on the ground and obtain early buy-in. Mitigation
label: other

text: strategy for a potential lack of transparency should be expanded in the model card and/or the
label: other

text: anticipatory action framework.
label: other

text: Inaction
label: other

text: Inaction refers to the situation in which drought impact is predicted but no action is taken.
label: other

text: Inaction in case of trigger activation is unlikely, given the pre-allocated financing attached to it
label: other

text: and the UN-validated anticipatory action framework. Inaction might nevertheless be a
label: other

text: possibility, if government or local authorities block the roll-out of interventions on the ground or
label: other

text: in case of conflict upsurge. The team could consider adding a consensus-based
label: other

text: decision-making option around activation or non-activation in the event of specific events or
label: other

text: situational context not considered in the model design (e.g., higher levels of vulnerability or
label: other

text: increase in armed conflict, etc.)

label: other

label: other
